chunks.original_text: ○疏：神道处阴，幽冥难测，由其得一，故灵智无方，故《庄子》云：神鬼神帝，生天生地也。 谷得一以盈， 注：言谷得一，故能满盈而不绝。 ○节解曰：谷谓。 也，。 为华池宫，能致醴泉，故日以盈。 ○疏：谷，川谷也。 言谷得一故能泉源流润，汉壑盈满。 万物得一以生， 注：言万物皆须道以生成也。 ○疏：有识有情，通号万物，同禀一道，故得生成。 ○节解曰：谓万物异形，皆共得一以生，故日以生。 侯王得一以为天下正。 注：言侯王得一，故能为天下平正。 ○节解曰：谓脾也。 位处中黄，以一制化四方，故日以正。 ○疏：帝王公侯莫不察道为化，只以无为得一，故能布政天下，放勋文命是也。 其致之， 注：言致诫也，谓下六事也。 ○御曰：物得道用，因用立名，道存则名立，用失则实丧。 故天清、地宁、神灵、谷盈，皆资妙用以政之，故云其政之。 ○疏：致，得也。 通结前六事，咸得一道也。 内解云：通是一人而有六种行门也。 ○节解曰：谓天地人神灵水泉万物各共一以成，故曰其致之也。 天无以清将恐裂， 注：言天，当有阴阳弛张，昼夜更用事，不可但欲清明无已时，将恐分裂不为天也。 ○节解曰：谓泥丸不得一，则脑桔头白齿落，故日裂。 地无以宁将恐发， 注：言地当有高下刚柔，节气五行，不可但欲安静气无已时，将恐发泄不为地也。 ○疏：发，变动也。 言地不能用道宁静，则恐有崩沦之灾。 昔岐山崩，三川震是也。 ○节解曰：谓丹田不得一，则精气发泄，故日恐发也。 神无以灵将恐歇， 注：言神当有王相死囚休废，不可但欲灵变无已时，恐虚歇不为神也。 ○节解曰：谓心乱不守一，则身空早老，故日恐歇。 ○疏：歇，废也。 神不依道则智用愚怠，既无灵验，将恐歇灭也。 谷无以盈将恐竭， 注：言谷当有盈缩虚实，不可但欲盈满无已时，将恐枯竭不为谷也。 ○节解曰：谓。 失其一，则华池不津液，故日竭也。 ○疏：竭，塞也。 言川谷乖一，灾否斯起，致泉源枯竭，流注不通也。 万物无以生将恐灭， 注：言万物生长收藏，当随时死生，不可但欲长生无已时，将恐灭亡不为物也。 ○疏：一切万物得一而生，若丧道乖真，则死灭俄顷。 侯王无以贵高将恐蹶。 注：言侯王当屈己下人，汲汲求贤，不可但欲高贵，於人无已时，将恐颠蹶失其位也。 ○御曰：夫得一者不可以矜其用，圣人垂教，本为生灵，虽远举天地清宁，而会归只在侯王谦和，守於雌静之道，则无蹶灭等事。 ○疏：蹶，败也。 君王不能用道守贵，乖理勃德，将恐神器类覆，社稷倾危，夏桀殷纣，即其人也。 故贵必以贱为本， 注：言必欲尊贵者，当以薄贱为本，若禹稷躬耕，舜陶河滨，周公下白屋也。 ○节解曰：谓人求－长生，当以元气为母，故日本也。 ○疏：贵，尊高也。 贱，卑下也。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao/Way** dwells in **yin**, dark and unfathomable,
　　○*Commentary:* By its **Oneness**, it achieves boundless **aliveness** and **wisdom**, hence *Zhuangzi* says: *"The spirits and the **Dao/Way**’s **Imperial Sovereign** (神帝) generate the heavens and the earth."*

The **valleys** (谷) attained **Oneness** with **fullness** (盈),
　　○*Jie’s Interpretation:* The **valleys**—that is, the **Huaxi Palace** (华池宫)—can summon the **elixir spring** (醴泉), hence it is said "with **fullness**."

　　○*Commentary:* The **valleys** (谷) are mountain basins. By attaining **Oneness**, they can nourish flowing springs and fill the **Han moats** (汉壑) with abundance.

The **ten thousand things** (万物) attained **Oneness** with **birth** (生),
　　○*Commentary:* All sentient and insentient beings, collectively called the **ten thousand things**, share **Oneness** with the **Dao/Way**, hence they come to **birth** and **manifestation**.

　　○*Jie’s Interpretation:* It means that all things, though of varied forms, equally attain **Oneness** with the **Dao/Way** to bring forth life, hence it is said "with **birth**."

The **feudal lords and kings** (侯王) attained **Oneness** to govern the **world** (天下) with **rectitude** (正).
　　○*Commentary:* Feudal lords and kings alike observe the **Dao/Way** to transform, and by embracing **non-action** (无为) to attain **Oneness**, they can administer the world’s **affairs** (政). The examples are **Fangxun** (放勋) and **Wenming** (文命).

　　○*Jie’s Interpretation:* It refers to the **spleen** (脾). Positioned in the **central yellow** (中黄), it governs the four directions through **Oneness**, hence it is said "with **rectitude**."

The **Dao/Way’s** **manifestation** (致) is thus,
　　○*Yu’s Interpretation:* When things attain the **Dao/Way**, they are named accordingly. The **Dao/Way** persists, names stand; the **Dao/Way** fades, reality perishes. Hence, the heavens’ **clarity**, the earth’s **tranquility**, the **spirit’s** **aliveness**, and the **valleys’** **fullness** all arise from **wondrous application** (妙用) of the **Dao/Way**, thus it is said "its **manifestation**."

　　○*Commentary:* **Manifestation** (致) means **attainment**. It unifies the preceding six affairs, all of which attain **Oneness** with the **Dao/Way**. The *Inner Resolution* says: "This is the **sixfold practice** (六种行门) of a single individual."

　　○*Jie’s Interpretation:* It means that the heavens, earth, humans, **spirit**, **elixir waters**, **springs**, and the **ten thousand things** all attain **Oneness** to manifest, hence it is said "its **manifestation**."

The heavens, without **clarity**, would fear **rupture** (裂),
　　○*Jie’s Interpretation:* If the **marrow pellet** (泥丸) does not attain **Oneness**, then the **brain** (脑) will wither, the **head’s white** (桔头白) will fade, and the **teeth** (齿) will fall out, hence it is said "rupture."

The earth, without **tranquility**, would fear **outburst** (发),
　　○*Jie’s Interpretation:* If the **elixir field** (丹田) does not attain **Oneness**, then the **essence-qi** (精气) will dissipate, hence it is said "fear **outburst**."

　　○*Commentary:* **Outburst** (发) means **change and movement**. If the earth cannot apply the **Dao/Way** to remain **tranquil**, then disasters like **collapse** (崩沦) may arise. In ancient times, the **Qishan mountain** (岐山) collapsed, causing the **three rivers** (三川) to tremble—this is the case.

The **spirit**, without **aliveness**, would fear **extinction** (歇),
　　○*Jie’s Interpretation:* If the **heart** (心) is disordered and does not uphold **Oneness**, then the body will **hollow out** (空) and age prematurely, hence it is said "fear **extinction**."

　　○*Commentary:* **Extinction** (歇) means **decay**. If the **spirit** does not rely on the **Dao/Way**, then **wisdom and application** (智用) will grow **stupid and sluggish** (愚怠), lacking **aliveness**, and will fear **extinction** and **obliteration**.

The **valleys**, without **fullness**, would fear **exhaustion** (竭),
　　○*Jie’s Interpretation:* If the **Huaxi Palace** (华池宫) loses its **Oneness**, then it will lack **vital fluids** (津液), hence it is said "exhaustion."

　　○*Commentary:* **Exhaustion** (竭) means **blockage**. If the **valleys** (川谷) deviate from **Oneness**, then calamities will begin, causing the **springs** to dry up and the **flowing channels** (流注) to stagnate.

The **ten thousand things**, without **birth**, would fear **annihilation** (灭),
　　○*Commentary:* All the **ten thousand things** attain **birth** through **Oneness** with the **Dao/Way**; if they lose the **Dao/Way** and deviate from **truth**, then they will perish in an instant.

The **feudal lords and kings**, without **nobility and elevation** (贵高), would fear **overthrow** (蹶),
　　○*Yu’s Interpretation:* Those who attain **Oneness** must not boast of their **application**. The **Sages** (圣人) taught that their purpose is for the **living beings** (生灵), though they may elevate the heavens and earth to **clarity** and **tranquility**, their ultimate convergence lies in the **feudal lords and kings** practicing **humility** (谦和) and adhering to the **Dao/Way of female stillness** (雌静), thus avoiding **overthrow** or **annihilation**.

　　○*Commentary:* **Overthrow** (蹶) means **ruin**. If rulers cannot apply the **Dao/Way** to maintain their **nobility**, acting against **principle** (理) and **virtue** (德), then their **divine instruments** (神器) will fall into **disorder**, and their **states** (社稷) will face **peril**. The tyrants **Jie of Xia** (夏桀) and **Zhou of Shang** (殷纣) are such examples.

Thus, **nobility** must take **humility** as its foundation,
　　○*Jie’s Interpretation:* It means that those who seek **long life** (长生) must regard **original qi** (元气) as their **mother**, hence it is said "its foundation."

　　○*Commentary:* **Nobility** (贵) refers to **elevation** and **exaltation**. **Humility** (贱) means **lowliness**.

chunks.original_text: 得一之君，故能谦下，失道之主，叉致骄矜，故知骄矜是下贱之基，谦卑是尊高之本，校量得失，故有斯戒。 高必以下为基。 注：言必欲尊贵，当以下为本基，犹筑墙造功，因卑成高，下不坚固，后必倾危也。 ○节解曰：谓道人养精补脑，当用丹田为主，故为基也。 ○顾日：夫言高以下为基者，贵非自贵，由乎贱者所崇，高非自高，绿於下者所载。 然则贵因贱立，得不以贱为本乎。 是以智者务本，故居谦而不危。 愚者殉末，故穷高而自坠。 是以侯王自谓孤寡不毂。 注：言孤寡者，喻孤独也。 不毂，喻不能如车毂为众辐所奏也。 王侯至尊贵，能以孤寡自称，此非以贱为本乎。 以晓示於人也。 ○疏：不毂，犹不善也。 王侯贵人智慧，聪达体知，傲是丧身之本，谦是贵盛之基，故抚接下凡，以卑自牧，乃称孤寡不毂。 ○顾曰：所以言不毂者，不善也。 谓德非物宗，不能总众之辞，凡上三者，皆人之所恶，而侯王自以为称，岂非以贱为本乎。 此其以贱为本也，非乎？ 注：言非乎者，盖是嗟叹假问之辞云耳。 ○节解曰：非谓其道是元一欤。 故致数车无车。 注：致，就也，人就车数之，为辐为轮为毂为衡为辕为轴，无有名为车者，故成为车。 以喻侯王不以尊号自名，故能成其贵。 ○疏：箱袭毂辋，假合而成，徒有车名，数即无实，五物四大为幻亦然，所以身既浮虚，贵将安寄，是以处贵应须谦下。 ○蔡曰：所言誉者，毁誉也。 言有道王侯，卑以自牧，既忘贵贱，亦一毁誉，故人数数誉扬，言其有德，亦不以为贵，数数毁败，言其无道，亦不以为贱。 ○顾曰：言行人君子善以道德功行建立身心，无德可彰，无迹可显，则深根固蒂，不为是非，欲恶之所抽拔也。 不欲球绿如玉，落落如石。 御曰：琭琭，玉貌，落落，石貌。 以贱为本也。 反者道之动， 注：此明权也，反者取其反经合义。 反经合义者，是圣人行权，行权者是道之运动，故云反者道之动。 弱者道之用也。 注：此明实也。
chunks.translated_text:
The ruler who attains **Oneness** (得一之君) thus remains humble,
while the ruler who loses the **Dao/Way** (失道之主) falls into arrogance and pride.
Hence, arrogance and pride are the foundation of lowliness,
and humility is the root of exaltation.
By measuring gain and loss,
one establishes this admonition.

**Exaltation** must take **humility** as its foundation.
○*Annotation:* It means that if one seeks true nobility,
they must take **humility** as their foundation—
just as when building walls or structures,
one must first establish a low base;
if the foundation is not firm,
the structure will inevitably collapse.

○*Jie’s Interpretation:* It means that those who cultivate **Dao/Way** to nourish **essence** (精) and supplement the **marrow** (脑) must use the **elixir field** (丹田) as their foundation—
thus, it is the foundation.

○*Gu’s Commentary:* Those who speak of **exaltation** taking **humility** as its foundation
do not attain nobility by themselves—
they are elevated by what the lowly revere.
They do not rise by themselves—
they are borne aloft by what is beneath them.
Thus, nobility depends on humility—
how could one not take **humility** as the root?

Therefore, the wise cultivate the foundation,
and thus remain humble without peril.
The foolish pursue superficiality,
and thus reach for heights only to fall.

Hence, rulers call themselves **"lonely and bereft"** (孤寡).
○*Annotation:* **"Lonely"** (孤) signifies solitude,
**"bereft"** (寡) signifies inability—
like a wheel hub (毂) that cannot be the center
for all spokes to gather.
Though kings and lords are most exalted,
they call themselves thus—
is this not taking **humility** as their foundation,
to enlighten the people?

○*Commentary:* **"Bereft"** (不毂) means unworthy.
Rulers, wise and enlightened,
know that arrogance is the root of self-destruction,
while humility is the foundation of true nobility.
Thus, they govern the common people,
shepherding themselves with humility.

○*Gu’s Commentary:* **"Bereft"** (不毂) means unworthy.
It means that **virtue** (德) is not something to be worshipped—
one cannot command the words of the multitude.
All three of these—
the ruler’s self-designation, the people’s revulsion,
and the ruler’s own humility—
are ways of taking **humility** as the foundation.
Is this not so?
○*Annotation:* **"Is this not so?"** (非乎) is merely an exclamatory rhetorical question.

○*Jie’s Interpretation:* It is not that their **Dao/Way** is **Original Oneness** (元一).
Thus, they achieve **"ten thousand chariots without a chariot"** (致数车无车).
○*Annotation:* **"Achieve"** (致) means to gather—
people gather around the chariot’s components:
spokes, wheels, hub, yoke, axle, and shaft,
yet none of these is called a chariot;
only when assembled do they become one.
Thus, rulers do not name themselves by their exalted titles,
and so their nobility is complete.

○*Commentary:* The box, cover, hub, and rim—
artificial combinations—
though called a chariot, lack true substance.
The five elements and four great forces are likewise illusory;
since the body is inherently empty,
where then would nobility reside?
Thus, when in a position of nobility,
one must practice humility.

○*Cai’s Commentary:* **"Praise"** (誉) refers to both praise and blame.
It means that a **Dao/Way**-governed ruler,
humble in self-cultivation,
forgets distinctions of nobility and lowliness,
and thus transcends both praise and blame.
Though people frequently extol his virtues,
he does not consider himself noble;
though they frequently condemn his failings,
he does not consider himself lowly.

○*Gu’s Commentary:* It means that the **noble person** (君子) establishes **moral cultivation** (道德功行) in mind and body.
Without virtue to display,
without traces to reveal,
their roots run deep and their foundations are firm—
unshaken by praise or blame,
desire or aversion.

**"Do not be polished like jade, nor rigid like stone."**
○*Yu’s Annotation:* **"Jing-jing"** (琭琭) describes jade’s appearance,
**"luo-luo"** (落落) describes stone’s appearance.
This is taking **humility** as the foundation.

**"The inverted is the movement of the Dao."**
○*Annotation:* This clarifies **strategic adaptation** (权).
**"The inverted"** refers to reversing conventional principles to align with meaning.

**"The weak is the application of the Dao."**
○*Annotation:* This clarifies **substance** (实).

chunks.original_text: 弱者取其柔弱雌静，雌静者，是圣人处实。 处实者，是道之常用，故云弱者道之用也。 天下万物生於有， 注：天下万物皆从天地生，天地有形位，故言生於有。 有生於无。 注：天地神明，蜎飞蠕动，皆从道生，道无形象，故言生於无也，此言本胜於华，弱胜於强，谦虚胜盈满也。 ○御曰：夫实之於权，犹无之生有，故行权者贵反於实，用有者必资於无，然至道冲寂，离於名称，诸法性空，不相因待，若能两忘权实，双泯有无，则数舆无舆，可谓超出矣。 ○疏：有，应道也，所谓无一之气也。 元一妙本，所谓冥寂之地，言天地万物，皆从应道有法而生，即此应从妙本而起。 妙本即至无也。 上士闻道，勤而行之； 注：上士闻道，勤苦竭力而行之。 ○疏：上机之人，智慧聪达，一闻至道，即悟万法皆空，所以勤苦修学，遂无疑怠。 中士闻道，若存若亡； 注：中士闻道，治身以长生，治国以太平，欣然而存之，退见财色荣誉，惑於情欲，而复亡之。 ○御曰：中士可上可下，故疑惑，则若存若亡。 ○疏：中机智暗，照理不明，虽复闻道，未能妙悟，若敛情归定，即时得虚心，才涉世尘，则滞於有境，与夺不定，故云存亡。 下士闻道，大笑之。 注：下士贪狠多欲，见道柔弱，谓之恐惧，见道质朴，谓之鄙陋，故大笑。 ○疏：下机之人，机性愚钝，闻真道玄远，至言弘博，心既不悟，谓之虚诞，遂生诽谤，抚掌大笑也。 不笑不足以为道。 注：不为下士所笑者，不足名之为道。 ○疏：不为凡人所笑，不足称为圣道。 是以建言有之： 注：建设之道也。 设言已有道，当如下六句。 ○疏：建，立也，言上士所行之道，建在下文有之，则明道若昧等是也。 明道若昧， 注：明道之人，若暗昧无所见知也。 ○疏：昧，暗也。 照达真道之人，昧迹同俗，不显其明，若愚昧也。 进道若退， 注：进取道者，若退不及也。 ○疏：大学之人，不见其逵，内虽进修，外若衰退。 夷道若类， 注：夷，平也，大道之人不自别殊，若多比类也。 上德若谷， 注：上德之人若深谷，不耻浊湿也。 ○疏：胜尚道德之人，与太虚等量，故能包容万物，若彼空谷也。 本欲有作俗字者，言能忘德，不异嚣俗也。 大白若辱， 注：大洁白之人若污辱，不自彰显也。 ○疏：白，洁净也。 辱，污辱也。 言大洁白高行之人，和光同尘，不耀於物，故能混迹扬波，若污辱也。 故东方生洁其道而秽其迹，即斯义也。 广德若不足， 注：德行广大之人，若顽愚不足也。 ○御曰：大成而执谦也。 ○疏：言怀大德之士，体道虚忘，故内至有余，而外若不足。 老子传云：良贾深藏若虚，盛德容貌若愚也。 建德若偷， 注：建设道德之人，若可偷引使空虚也。 ○疏：偷，盗也。 言建立大德之人，藏名匿进，如彼偷窃不用人知，故上经云犹若畏四邻也。 质真若渝， 注：质朴之人，若五色有浅不明也。 ○御曰：淳一而和光也。 ○疏：  质，实也。 渝，变也，言素质体真之  士，寂而动，真而应，变见无常，故若  渝也。 大方无隅， 注：大方正之人，无委曲康隅也。 ○疏：隅，角也。 言体道大方之人，因循顺物，不守节操，不立小隅角，所谓上达无节也。 大器晚成， 注：大器之人，若九鼎瑚琏，不可仓卒而成也。
chunks.translated_text:
The weak is taken for its yielding softness and receptive stillness—
receptive stillness is how the Sage abides in substance.
To abide in substance is the Dao’s constant application,
thus it is said: *The weak is the Dao’s use.*

All things under Heaven are born of *having*,
*—for all things arise from Heaven and Earth’s form and place.*
Having is born of *non-being*,
*—for Heaven and Earth’s mysteries, the fluttering and crawling of life,*
*all arise from the Dao, which is formless and nameless.*
This speaks of the root prevailing over the flourishing,
the weak prevailing over the strong,
humility prevailing over fullness.

○*Yu’s Commentary:*
Substance and strategy are like non-being generating having—
thus those who practice strategy must return to substance,
and those who employ having must rely on non-being.
Yet the ultimate Dao is boundless and silent,
free from names and forms.
All dharmas are of empty nature,
not dependent on each other.
If one can forget both strategy and substance,
and merge having and non-being,
then neither counting nor not-counting exists—
this may be called transcendence.

○*Exegesis:*
*Having* is the Dao’s manifestation—
the so-called *One Qi of non-being*.
The primal One is the wondrous root—
the so-called *silent and empty realm*.
All things under Heaven arise from the Dao’s manifested laws,
and these laws themselves arise from the wondrous root—
the ultimate non-being.

The superior person hears the Dao and strives to practice it.
*—The superior person, upon hearing the Dao, exerts utmost effort to practice it.*

○*Exegesis:*
The superior in wisdom, hearing the Dao,
instantly comprehends that all phenomena are empty,
thus they diligently cultivate without hesitation or laziness.

The middle person hears the Dao and holds it uncertainly.
*—The middle person, hearing the Dao,*
*seeks longevity through self-cultivation,*
*and seeks peace for the realm,*
*yet when confronted with wealth, desire, or honor,*
*they are confused by passions and abandon it.*

○*Yu’s Commentary:*
The middle person may ascend or descend,
thus they are doubtful—
sometimes holding, sometimes losing.

○*Exegesis:*
The middle in wisdom, dim in insight,
cannot fully grasp the principles.
Though they hear the Dao, they fail to penetrate its depths.
If they restrain their emotions and return to stillness,
they may briefly attain emptiness of mind,
but once immersed in worldly affairs,
they become entangled in the realm of having,
vacillating between gain and loss—
thus it is said: *uncertain holding or losing.*

The inferior person hears the Dao and laughs at it.
*—The inferior person, greedy and desiring,*
*sees the Dao’s softness as terrifying,*
*sees its simplicity as vulgar,*
*thus they laugh loudly.*

○*Exegesis:*
The inferior in wisdom, dull and obtuse,
hearing the profound and vast truths of the Dao,
fail to comprehend and deem them empty fables,
thus they scoff and laugh aloud.

If it is not laughed at, it is not the Dao.
*—That which is not laughed at by the inferior is not worthy to be called the Dao.*

○*Exegesis:*
That which is not scorned by the vulgar
is not worthy to be called the Sage’s Way.

Thus, the establishment of speech is as follows:
*—The method of establishing the Dao is as in the six lines below.*

○*Exegesis:*
*Establishment*—to set forth.
The Dao practiced by the superior is established in the following:

The enlightened one appears as if in darkness,
*—The one who illuminates the Dao*
*appears as if blind and ignorant,*
*concealing their brilliance among the common.*

The one advancing in the Dao appears as if retreating,
*—The great scholar*
*does not reveal their progress,*
*though internally cultivating,*
*externally they seem to decline.*

The one in harmony with the Dao blends with the common,
*—*Harmony*—levelness.
The great Daoist does not distinguish themselves,
appearing as if among many.*

The Sage’s virtue is like a deep valley,
*—The Sage of highest virtue*
*is like a valley,*
*unashamed by filth or dampness.*

○*Exegesis:*
The one who excels in moral cultivation
is equal to the boundless void,
thus they can embrace all things,
like an empty valley.
*[Original note:]* Those who forget virtue
do not differ from the vulgar.

The greatly pure appear as if shamed,
*—The greatly pure and virtuous*
*appear as if stained,*
*not displaying themselves.*

○*Exegesis:*
*Purity*—cleanness.
*Shame*—defilement.
The one of great purity and high conduct
blends with the dust,
does not dazzle others,
thus they can mix unnoticed—
like defilement.

Hence, the Eastern Sage purifies their Way
while staining their traces—
this is the very meaning.

The broadly virtuous appear insufficient,
*—The one of vast virtue*
*appears as if foolish and lacking.*

○*Yu’s Commentary:*
Great achievement while holding humility.

○*Exegesis:*
The one bearing great virtue,
abiding in Daoic forgetfulness,
internally overflows,
yet externally appears deficient.

Laozi’s transmission states:
*The skilled merchant hides deeply like emptiness,*
*The Sage of great virtue appears as if foolish.*

The one establishing virtue appears as if deceitful,
*—The one establishing morality*
*appears as if stealing,*
*hiding their name and progress,*
*like one who acts secretly,*
*thus the Classic says:*
*‘As if fearing their neighbors.’*

The genuine appear as if false,
*—The genuine and sincere*
*appear as if their colors fade,*
*unclear.*

○*Yu’s Commentary:*
Pure and harmonious in light.

○*Exegesis:*
*Genuine*—substance.
*False*—change.
The scholar of pure substance,
still yet moving,
true yet responsive,
their changes reveal impermanence—
thus they appear as if false.

The great square has no corners,
*—The great and square*
*has no crookedness or angles.*

○*Exegesis:*
*Corner*—angle.
The one embodying the great square
follows things naturally,
does not cling to principles,
does not establish petty angles—
as said: *‘The superior transcends all nodes.’*

Great vessels take long to mature,
*—The great vessel*
*is like the Nine Cauldrons and coral ornaments,*
*not formed hastily.*

chunks.original_text: ○疏：瑚琏九鼎，非一朝可成，喻大学之人，岂近心能证，必须累劫修守，方政虚极，即任公子钓惊是也。 ○节解曰：谓守一不殆，老则得道。 大音希声， 注：大音犹雷霆，待时而动，喻当爱气希言。 ○疏：希，犹无也。 至道至虚，大音寂乎无响，自妙本降迹无声也。 师旷听而不闻其声也。 琼音振於宇宙，欲明是迹即本，故言大音希声。 大象无形， 注：大法象之人，质朴无形容。 ○疏：大道之象，象而无形也。 离娄视之而莫见其形也，色像遍乎虚空，欲明即有而无，故云大象无形也。 道隐无名。 注：道港隐使人无能指名也。 ○疏：至道妙本，幽隐窈冥，非形器之所测量，岂名言之能诠辩也。 夫唯道，善贷且成。 注：成，就也。 言道善禀贷人精气且成就之也。 ○疏：贷，借也。 独此无名之道，有大慈悲，故能俯救众生，借其善力，亭毒群品，生化三才，种种方便，趣令成就。 道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 注：道生一，道始所生者一也。 一生二，一生阴阳也。 二生三，阴阳生和清浊三气，分为天地人也。 三生万物，天地人共生万物也，天施地化，人长养之。 ○荣曰：道生一，虚中动气，故日道生。 元气未分，故言一也。 一生二，清浊分，阴阳着也。 二生三，运二气三才。 三生万物，圆天覆於上，方地载於下，人主统於中，何物不生也。 万物负阴而抱阳， 注：万物无不负阴而向阳，回心而就日也。 陈曰：阴阳，道之妙用也，负则在外，抱则在内。 #1 冲气以为和。
chunks.translated_text:
○ *Exegesis:*
The Nine Cauldrons and coral ornaments
are not formed in a single day—
a parable for the scholar of the Great Learning,
who cannot swiftly attain enlightenment.
They must accumulate eons of cultivation and vigilance
before attaining the utmost emptiness—
thus the tale of *Ren’s Son* fishing in astonishment.

○ *Sectional Analysis:*
It speaks of steadfastly abiding in the One without peril,
and thus, in aging, attaining the Dao.

*The Great Sound is rare in voice,*
*—The Great Sound, like thunder,*
*awaits its moment to move—*
*a metaphor for cherishing qi and sparing speech.*

○ *Exegesis:*
*Rare*—as if nonexistent.
The utmost Dao, in its profound silence,
descends from its wondrous origin without a trace of sound.
The Master Blind could hear yet not perceive its voice.
The resonant *Qiong* vibrates through the cosmos,
to illuminate the manifestation as the origin—
thus it is said: *The Great Sound is rare in voice.*

*The Great Image is formless,*
*—The one embodying the Great Law’s symbol*
*is unadorned and without outward appearance.*

○ *Exegesis:*
The Dao’s symbol is formless yet manifest.
*Li Lou* gazes yet sees no shape—
its hues pervade the void,
to reveal the paradox of presence within absence—
hence, *The Great Image is formless.*

*The Way is hidden, nameless.*
*—The Dao’s depths elude all designation.*

○ *Exegesis:*
The utmost Dao, in its mysterious obscurity,
defies measurement by form or instrument—
how could mere names or speech ever explicate it?

Only the Dao
is benevolent in lending and fulfilling.
*—To fulfill*—to complete.

○ *Exegesis:*
*Lending*—borrowing.
This nameless Dao alone possesses boundless compassion,
thus stooping to rescue all beings.
It borrows their virtuous strength,
shielding all classes from poison,
nurturing the Three Realms,
through myriad expedients,
guiding them toward fulfillment.

*The Dao generates the One,*
*The One generates the Two,*
*The Two generates the Three,*
*The Three generates the Ten Thousand Things.*

*—The Dao generates the One*—the Dao’s first generation is the One.
*—The One generates the Two*—the One generates yin and yang.
*—The Two generates the Three*—yin and yang generate the three qi of harmony, purity, and turbidity, partitioning into Heaven, Earth, and Man.
*—The Three generates the Ten Thousand Things*—Heaven, Earth, and Man together generate the Ten Thousand Things, as Heaven bestows, Earth transforms, and Man nourishes them.

○ *Honor’s Commentary:*
*The Dao generates the One*—within the void, qi stirs, hence *the Dao generates*.
Before primordial qi divides, it is called the One.
*The One generates the Two*—pure and turbid separate, yin and yang manifest.
*The Two generates the Three*—the two qi circulate through the Three Realms.
*The Three generates the Ten Thousand Things*—the round Heaven covers above, the square Earth bears below, and Man governs between—what thing fails to emerge?

*The Ten Thousand Things bear yin while embracing yang,*
*—The Ten Thousand Things without fail bear yin while turning toward yang,*
*returning to the heart and seeking the sun.*

○ *Chen’s Commentary:*
Yin and yang are the Dao’s wondrous functions—
*bear* means external, *embrace* means internal.

#1 *The clashing qi harmonizes.*

chunks.original_text: 注：万物之中皆有元气，得以和柔，若胸中有藏，骨中有髓，草木中有空虚，和气潜通，故得长生。 ○荣曰：阳气热孤，亦不能生物，阴气寒单，亦不足成形。 因大道以通之，借冲气以和之，所以得生也。 人之所恶，唯孤寡不谷，而王公以为称。 注：孤寡不者，谷不祥之名，而王公以为称者，处谦卑，法空虚和柔也。 ○疏：孤独鳏寡，乃不善之事，以此为恶，人之常情。 而王公贵人用斯自牧，足明贵以贱为本，高以下为基，以劝修行之人，必须处心谦顺。 故物或损之而益， 注：引之不得推让心还，文子曰：争则不足，让则有余，让则礼义生，争则暴乱起。 益之而损。 注：夫增高者玫崩，贪富者政息。 ○御曰：自损者，人益之。 自益者，人损之。 故朝宗者善於下，谦弱者德之柄，孤寡为称，不亦宜乎。 御疏曰：故者，仍上之辞也。 损，贬毁也。 言王公称孤寡以自毁损，则为百姓乐推，尊敬而事之而政益也。 或益之而损者，若王公贵宠其身，居上而骄，则下人离散而玫损也。 《书》曰：满招损，谦受益，斯之谓也。 ○成疏：谦卑柔弱，损己济物，物必归之，故生道获全。 矜夸傲诞，益己凌物，物必挫之，故致危败。 危败是损，全生是益，损益之验，其义尽然，故言损之而益，益之而损也。 人之所教， 注：谓众人所教我去弱为强，去柔为刚。 我亦义教之。 注：言我教众人，使去强为弱，去刚为柔。 ○御曰：老君云：人君所欲立教教人者，当以吾此柔弱谦虚之义以教之也。 ○疏：言俗人儒教亦尚谦柔，我之法门，本崇静退，贵在虚忘，所以为异。 强梁者不得其死， 注：强梁者，谓不信玄妙，背叛道德，不从经教，尚势任力也。 不得其死者，为天命所绝，兵刃所伐，王法所杀，不得以寿终而死也。 吾将以为教父。 注：父，始也。 老君以强梁之人以为教戒之始也。 ○御曰：吾见强粱者亡，柔弱者全，故以此柔弱之教为众教之父。 ○疏：强粱犹刚躁也，父，始也。 言强梁之人必当夭折，不得依於天命寿终而死也。 老君虽复演法多端，教门匪一，而每说柔弱为善，刚强为恶，以此切当将为学道之先。 父亦本也。 ○顾曰：言此强梁之士，既不得其死，我即为其立教，说斯无为道德，作其教学之本父也。 天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚。 注：至柔者水也，至坚者金石也。 水能贯坚入刚，无所不通也。 ○疏：至柔，水也。 至坚，金也。 驰骋，贯穿之义也。 言水至柔能攻金石之坚，喻无为至柔能破有为之累，故下文云天下柔弱，莫过於水，攻坚强者，莫之能先也。 无有入无间， 注：无有谓道也，道无形质，故能出入无间，通神明，济群生也。 ○御曰：无有者，不染尘境也，心中无所有也。 无间者，道性自然清净，妙体混成，一无问隙。 夫不为可欲所乱，令心境俱静，一无所有，则心与道合契，出入无间。 ○疏：间，隙也。 言颠倒之流，见空为有，达观之士，即有而空，故言无有也。 入，契会也，有为粗疏，故有隙。 无为微密，故无间也。 而即有即无，故能入无间之理也。 ○车曰：言水之与风，本无质相，金石骨髓，亦无间隙，风之与水，已能纵入，行之所攻。 至妙之道，本自无形，烦恼结陋，又无间窍，道之妙惠，早已入讫，原其结缚之由，要其顽执之本，投其悟解之药，开其正性之机，此即无有入无间也。

「Annotations:
*The Ten Thousand Things all contain primordial qi*—
by which they are harmonized and softened.
If in the chest there is a *藏* (hidden essence),
and in the bones there is *髓* (marrow),
then within grasses and trees there is *空虚* (emptiness/voidness),
and the harmonizing qi subtly pervades—
thus they attain longevity.

○ *Honor’s Commentary:*
Yang qi is hot and solitary—
it too cannot generate the Ten Thousand Things.
Yin qi is cold and lone—
it too is insufficient to form shape.
Through the *Great Dao* it is communicated,
and by the *clashing qi* it is harmonized—
thus the Ten Thousand Things come to be.

What men detest,
are the *孤寡不谷* (lonely, widowed, and unblessed),
yet kings and lords take them as their titles.
Annotations:
*The lonely, widowed, and unblessed*—
this is the name for *谷不祥* (unauspicious blessings),
yet kings and lords take them as their titles—
dwelling in humility,
and following the *voidness*, *emptiness*, and *softness*.

○ *Sparse Commentary:*
Loneliness and widowhood are matters of misfortune—
to abhor them is human nature.
Yet kings and nobles employ them to govern themselves,
proving that nobility stems from humility,
and exalted status rests on lowly foundations,
urging those who seek the Dao
to cultivate a humble and yielding heart.
Thus, some things are diminished when increased—
Annotations:
*If one pulls, it cannot be pushed*—
*Wenzi* says: *"To vie is to lack, to yield is to have excess.
To yield is to give rise to propriety and righteousness;
to vie is to spawn violence and chaos."*
—
and increased when diminished.

Annotations:
*Those who heap highness court collapse,
and those who covet wealth invite ruin.*

○ *Master’s Commentary:*
He who diminishes himself is benefited by others.
He who benefits himself is diminished by others.
Thus, those who *朝宗* (return to the root) excel in yielding,
and the humble and weak hold the reins of *德* (virtue).
For *孤寡* (lonely/widowed) to be a title—
is it not fitting?

○ *Master’s Sparse Commentary:*
*Thus*—reiterating the previous point.
*Diminished*—meaning self-abasement.
Speaking of kings and lords who adopt the titles of *孤寡* (lonely/widowed)
to humble themselves,
the people will joyfully promote them,
revering and serving them,
and the governance thus flourishes.
Or, when increased yet diminished—
if kings and nobles indulge their own bodies,
dwell above and grow arrogant,
then those below scatter and the realm collapses.
*The Book of Documents* says:
*"Fullness invites loss, humility invites gain"—
this is what is meant.

○ *Cheng’s Commentary:*
Humility and softness,
diminishing oneself to aid others—
things will naturally gravitate toward him,
thus attaining the Dao and preserving wholeness.
Arrogance and boasting,
increasing oneself to dominate others—
things will resist him,
thus inviting peril and ruin.
Peril and ruin are *损* (loss),
wholeness and life are *益* (gain)—
the verification of loss and gain
is entirely manifest,
thus it is said:
*to diminish is to gain*,
*to increase is to lose*.

What men are taught—
Annotations:
*That the common people are taught to forsake weakness for strength,
and softness for rigidity.*
—
I too instruct them with righteousness.
Annotations:
*Saying that I teach the common people
to forsake strength for weakness,
and rigidity for softness.*

○ *Master’s Commentary:*
The *Laozi* says:
*"When a ruler desires to establish teachings to teach the people,
he must use my doctrine of softness, weakness, humility, and emptiness to instruct them."*

○ *Sparse Commentary:*
The vulgar and those of the *儒* (Confucian) teachings also extol humility and softness,
yet my school’s gate
originally reveres stillness and retreat,
values emptiness and forgetfulness—
thus it differs.

The *强梁* (unyielding/rigid) do not die naturally—
Annotations:
*The unyielding*—those who do not trust in *玄妙* (mystic profundity),
rebel against *道德* (Daoist virtue),
do not follow the *经教* (scriptures and teachings),
and rely on power and force.
*Do not die naturally*—meaning they are cut off by fate,
slain by arms,
executed by royal law,
and do not attain death by natural lifespan.
I shall make them my *教父* (teaching progenitor).
Annotations:
*Progenitor*—the origin.

○ *Master’s Commentary:*
I have seen the unyielding perish,
and the soft and weak preserved—
thus I make this teaching of softness and weakness
the progenitor of all teachings.

○ *Sparse Commentary:*
*Unyielding*—akin to *刚躁* (rigidity and impetuosity).
*Progenitor*—the origin.
Speaking of those who are rigid and unyielding—
they must surely die young,
and cannot rely on fate to die naturally.
Though the *Laozi* expounds the law in myriad ways,
and his teachings are not singular,
he always says that softness and weakness are good,
and rigidity and strength are evil—
this is the most critical point
for those who seek the Dao to grasp first.
*Progenitor*—origin.

○ *Gu’s Commentary:*
Speaking of these rigid and unyielding men—
since they do not die naturally,
I establish this teaching for them,
explaining the *无为* (effortless Daoist virtue),
and making it the foundational progenitor of their instruction.

*The utmost softness in the world,*
*drives through the utmost firmness in the world.*
Annotations:
*The utmost softness*—water.
*The utmost firmness*—metal and stone.
Water can penetrate rigidity,
and enter strength—
it flows through all without obstruction.

○ *Sparse Commentary:*
*Utmost softness*—water.
*Utmost firmness*—metal.
*Drives through*—to penetrate.
Speaking of water’s utmost softness
yet ability to break through metal’s firmness—
it illustrates that the *无为* (effortless Dao)
in its utmost softness
can shatter the burdens of *有为* (worldly striving).
Thus the following passage says:
*"The world’s soft and weak,
none surpass water—
in attacking rigidity and strength,
none can rival it."*

*Without form, it enters the formless.*
Annotations:
*Without form*—the Dao.
The Dao has no substance or quality,
thus it can emerge and enter without obstruction,
communing with the divine,
and benefiting all living things.

○ *Master’s Commentary:*
*Without form*—untainted by mundane realms,
and the heart holds nothing.
*Without obstruction*—the Dao’s nature is naturally pure and clear,
its subtle body unified and complete,
with no gaps or separations.
If one is not disrupted by desires,
and both heart and realm are still,
holding nothing at all,
then the heart aligns with the Dao,
and emerges and enters without obstruction.

○ *Sparse Commentary:*
*Obstruction*—gaps.
Speaking of those who are deluded—
they see emptiness as having form,
while those who perceive truthfully
see form as emptiness—
thus *without form*.
*Enter*—harmonious resonance.
*有为* (worldly striving) is coarse and sparse,
thus it has gaps.
*无为* (effortless Dao) is subtle and refined,
thus it has no obstruction.
Yet in both form and emptiness,
it can enter the formless principle.

○ *Che’s Commentary:*
Speaking of water and wind—
they originally have no substance or form,
metal and stone, marrow—
they too have no gaps or obstructions.
Wind and water can already
penetrate and traverse,
and their attacks are relentless.
The most wondrous Dao
is inherently formless—
karmic entanglements and coarse habits
also lack gaps or openings.
The Dao’s profound grace
has long since entered and permeated—
to trace the roots of their bonds,
to reveal the foundation of their stubbornness,
to administer the medicine of awakening,
to open the mechanism of their true nature—
this is *without form entering the formless*.」

chunks.original_text: 吾是以知无为有益。 注：吾见道无为而万物自化成，是以知无为之有益於人也。 不言之教， 注：道法不言，师之以身。 无为之益， 注：法道无为，治身有益精神，治国则有益於人，不烦劳也。 ○孙曰：柔能破刚，无能遣有，以是知无为之教，大益於人。 天下希及之。 注：天下者人主也，希能有及道之无为治身治国也。 ○疏：所谓不言，非关杜口。 在理即有即无，在教亦即言即默。 即言即默，故名不言之教。 即有即无，故名无为之益。 益既不益而益，教岂教而教哉，斯乃穷理尽性，盖世之谈，世间名教罕能及者，故言天下希及之。 ○顾曰：则天玄默，而风俗自移，故日不言之教。 法道无为，人物自化，故言无为之益。 名与身孰亲？ 注：名遂则身退也。 ○御曰：名者实之宾，世人徇名以亡身，故设问谁亲，欲令去功与名，而全其真。 ○疏：身，内也，实也。 名，外也，宾也。 孰，谁也。 世人皆求外丧内，贪名丧实，何者？ 夫令誉芳名，本为身也，身既为名，身死名竟何施。 老君愍兹颠倒，故覆云名之与身，谁是汝亲乎，而汝贪名忘身耶。 以斯格量，亲疏可见，故《庄子》云：伯夷死名於首阳之下也。 身与货孰多？ 注：财多则害身。 ○御曰：徇多将以求财，财得而亡身，故设问孰多，欲令掷玉毁珠，以全其身。 ○疏：夫资货者，本为我身，迷惑之徒，丧身徇货，故老君责言汝去货存身利多，为聚货丧身利多耶。 故《庄子》云：盗跖死利於束陵之上。 得与亡孰病？ 注：好得利则病於行也。 ○疏：夫多责得财必丧己，少欲亡货则存身。 然则得是丧己之征，亡是存身之验，丧己可以为病，存身可以为乐，世人翻以得为适，以亡为病者，不亦谬乎。 故教主言：得与亡，定谁是病。 甚爱必大费， 注：甚爱色，费精神，甚爱财，遇祸患，所爱甚少，所亡者多，故言大费。 ○疏：费，损也。 为是义，故甚爱名誉之人，必劳形休心，费神损智，此一句解名也。 多藏必厚亡。 注：生多藏於府库，死多藏於丘墓，生有攻劫之忧，死有掘冢剖棺之息。 ○疏：夫多藏贿货於府库者，必有劫盗之息，非但丧失财物，亦乃害及己身，其为败亡，祸必深厚。 故《书》   云：匹夫无罪，怀璧其罪。 庄云：大儒胪，传曰：青青之麦，生於陵陂。 生不布施，死何含珠为。 於是以金锤控其颐，徐别其颊，无伤口中珠是也。 此一句解货。 知足不辱， 注：知足之人，绝利去欲，不辱其身。 ○疏：体知财贿虚假，守分不贪，清康知足，故无耻辱，此一句解货。 知止不殆， 注：知可止则止，财利不累於身心，声色不乱於耳目，终身不危殆也。 ○疏：既悟名誉非真，所以止而不着，全身远害，故无危殆。 上经云：名亦既有，夫亦将知止。 此一句结名。 可以长久。 注：人能知止足，则福禄常在於己，治身则神不劳，治国则民不扰，故可长久。 ○疏：知止於名，知足於货，忘名忘利，则可长可久。 此一句总结名。 道德真经注疏卷之四竟 #1案此条注文，见於道藏本陈象古《道德真经解》卷下。 象古为北宋末承议郎。 故可知本书应出於北宋末南宋初，绝非南齐顾欢所述，亦非唐人编集也。 道德真经注疏卷之五 吴郡征士顾欢述 大成若缺，

The Master thus knew that *effortless Dao* is beneficial.

**Commentary:**
I have seen the Dao of *effortless action*, yet all things spontaneously transform and complete themselves—thus I know that *effortless Dao* is beneficial to humanity.

The teaching of *unspeaking*,
**Commentary:**
The Dao’s method is unspeaking; the Sage guides by example.

The benefit of *effortless action*,
**Commentary:**
The Dao’s method is *effortless*—to cultivate the self benefits the spirit, to govern the realm benefits the people, and it avoids toil and labor.

○ Sun said:
Softness can overcome hardness; *nothingness* can dispel *somethingness*—thus it is known that the teaching of *effortless Dao* greatly benefits humanity.
Few in the world attain it.
**Commentary:**
The world’s ruler—few can approach the Dao’s *effortless* cultivation of self and governance.

○ Cushion:
What is called *unspeaking* is not about sealing the mouth.
In principle, it is both *having* and *not having*; in teaching, it is both *speaking* and *silence*.
Both *speaking* and *silence*—thus it is called the teaching of *unspeaking*.
Both *having* and *not having*—thus it is called the benefit of *effortless action*.
The benefit, though not a benefit, is indeed a benefit; the teaching, though not a teaching, is indeed a teaching.
This is the exhaustive exploration of principle and nature—rare discourse in the world.
Worldly teachings seldom reach this, hence it is said that few in the world attain it.

○ Gu said:
The Heavenly follows in silent mystery, yet customs shift naturally—thus it is called the teaching of *unspeaking*.
The Dao’s method is *effortless*; things and people transform spontaneously—thus it is called the benefit of *effortless action*.
Which is closer—*name* or *self*?
**Commentary:**
When *name* succeeds, the *self* retreats.

○ Yu said:
*Name* is the guest of *reality*; the world pursues *name* and loses the *self*—thus the question arises: which is closer?
It is to abandon merit and *name* and preserve the true.

○ Cushion:
*Self*—the inner, the real.
*Name*—the outer, the guest.
*Na* (who)—who.
The world seeks the outer and loses the inner, covets *name* and loses *reality*.
Why? Praise and fame are originally for the *self*—if the *self* is for *name*, when the *self* dies, what use is the *name*?
The Old Master pitied this inversion, thus he reversed: *Name* and *self*—which is truly yours?
Do you covet *name* and forget the *self*?
By this measure, closeness and distance become clear—thus *Zhuangzi* says:
*"Biyí died for his name beneath Chief Yang’s hill."*

Which is more—*self* or *wealth*?
**Commentary:**
Wealth multiplies and harms the *self*.

○ Yu said:
Pursuing abundance to seek wealth—wealth obtained, the *self* lost—thus the question arises: which is more?
It is to cast away jade and shatter pearls to preserve the *self*.

○ Cushion:
Wealth is originally for the *self*—deluded ones lose the *self* for wealth.
Thus the Old Master reproaches: *You abandon the self for wealth—wealth is more beneficial, or losing the self is more beneficial?*
Thus *Zhuangzi* says:
*"Zhoulu died for profit atop Mount Shunling."*

Which is the affliction—*gain* or *loss*?
**Commentary:**
Excessive desire for gain brings ruin in conduct.

○ Cushion:
To covet wealth excessively is to lose oneself; to desire little is to preserve the *self*.
Then *gain* is the sign of self-ruin, *loss* the proof of self-preservation.
Self-ruin is affliction; self-preservation is joy—yet the world reverses this, calling *gain* suitable and *loss* affliction.
How mistaken!
Thus the teaching says: *Gain and loss—determine which is the affliction.*

Excessive love brings great expenditure.
**Commentary:**
Excessive love of beauty wastes the spirit; excessive love of wealth invites calamity.
The more one loves, the less one retains—thus it is called great expenditure.

○ Cushion:
*Expenditure*—loss.
This is its meaning: those who love fame excessively labor their bodies and weary their minds, depleting their spirit and intelligence.
This sentence resolves *name*.

Hoarding much brings great loss.
**Commentary:**
The living hoard in treasuries; the dead are buried in graves.
The living face robbery and plunder; the dead face grave-robbing and coffin desecration.

○ Cushion:
Those who hoard wealth in treasuries must fear robbers—
not only losing their wealth but also endangering their lives.
Their ruin is deep and their calamity great.
Thus the *Book of Documents* says:
*"An ordinary man without guilt, yet his jade brings him guilt."*
*Zhuangzi* says:
*"The great scholar Luo recited:
Green wheat grows on the hillocks—
If not given in life, why hoard pearls in death?"*
Thus he struck his chin with a hammer and parted his cheeks—
lest the pearl in his mouth be harmed.
This sentence resolves *wealth*.

Knowing sufficiency brings no disgrace.
**Commentary:**
Those who know sufficiency cut off desires and avoid gain—
their bodies unshamed, their spirits at ease.

○ Cushion:
Understanding wealth’s falsity, guarding one’s portion, content and serene—
thus there is no shame.
This sentence resolves *wealth*.

Knowing when to stop brings no peril.
**Commentary:**
Knowing when to stop and stopping—
wealth and gain do not burden the body and mind,
sounds and colors do not confuse the ears and eyes—
thus one’s life is never in danger.

○ Cushion:
Having awakened to *name*’s falsity, one ceases attachment,
preserving the *self* and avoiding harm—
thus there is no peril.
The previous passage says:
*"Name has already been attained—
then one will know when to stop."*
This sentence concludes *name*.

Thus it can endure long.
**Commentary:**
If one knows when to stop, blessings and fortune abide with them.
Cultivating the self, the spirit is unwearied;
governing the realm, the people are undisturbed—
thus it can endure long.

○ Cushion:
Knowing when to stop with *name*, knowing sufficiency with *wealth*,
forgetting *name* and gain—
thus it can endure long.
This sentence summarizes *name*.

chunks.original_text: 注：谓道德大成之君也，若缺者，灭名藏誉，如毁缺不备也。 其用不弊。 注：其用心是则无弊尽时也。 ○御曰：谦则受益，故无困弊时也。 ○疏：言行业大成就之人，能忘其成，故虽大成，如似缺少不足也。 只为能忘其成，故终日货用而无弊损。 是以《庄子》云：小成隐道也。 夫成者不缺，缺者不成，而今成而似缺者，忘缺忘成。 故不见成而缺，故如缺而实成，不见缺而异成，故大成而似缺也。 大盈若冲， 注：谓道德大盈满之君，若冲者，贵不敢骄，富不敢奢。 其用不穷。 注：其用心如是，则无穷尽时也。 ○疏：冲，虚也。 静，尽也。 言道德大满之人，能满其满，故能满如似空虚无物也。 只为忘满冲虚，故能利用无竭也。 夫满者不虚，虚者不满，而今满而虚者，欲明忘满忘虚，故能即虚即满，满而若虚。 大直若屈， 注：大直谓修道法度正直如一也，若屈者，不与俗人争，如可屈折也。 ○疏：大直质素之人不显直相，故能混迹同尘，委曲随物，故若屈也。 是知直躬小直也。 大巧若拙， 注：大巧谓多才衍也，若拙者，亦不敢见其能也。 ○疏：匠成万物，炉锤群生，有大功巧而忘功用，晦迹同凡，故若拙也。 《庄子》云：雕刻众形而不为巧，是知工唾小巧也。 大辩若讷。 注：大辩者，智无疑。 如讷者，无口辞。 ○御曰：不饰小说也。 ○疏：妙能剖析真空，诠量玄极者，言所不能言也。 不同世间。 才捷利，故言蹇讷也。 《庄子》云：不言之辫，亦云大辫不言。 是知杨墨小辫也。 躁胜寒， 注：胜，极也。

Great completion, though seemingly incomplete,
*—Commentary:* This refers to the sovereign of supreme *Dao* and *virtue*—
though appearing incomplete, like a shattered vessel,
he extinguishes his *name* and conceals his merit.
Thus his use is unexhausted.
*—Commentary:* His mind, thus governed, knows no depletion with time.
*—Master Gu’s Explanation:* Humility brings benefit, so there is no time of want or ruin.
*—Exegesis:* The one whose deeds are fully accomplished
yet forgets his accomplishment—
though fully accomplished, he seems deficient.
Only because he forgets his accomplishment
does his wealth and use never diminish through time.

Thus does *Zhuangzi* say:
*"Small completion obscures the *Dao*."*

Now, completion is not incomplete,
incompleteness is not completion—
yet today, completion seems incomplete,
forgetting incompleteness, forgetting completion.
Thus, unseen is completion as incomplete,
so it seems incomplete yet is truly complete;
unseen is incompleteness as completion,
so great completion seems incomplete.

Great fullness is like emptiness,
*—Commentary:* This refers to the sovereign of supreme *Dao* and *virtue*—
though full, like emptiness, he does not dare to be proud in his nobility,
nor extravagant in his riches.
Thus his use is inexhaustible.
*—Commentary:* His mind, thus governed, knows no exhaustion with time.
*—Exegesis:* *Chong* is emptiness; *jing* is exhaustion.
The one whose *Dao* and *virtue* are fully satisfied
yet satisfies his fullness—
thus, though full, he seems empty and void.
Only because he forgets fullness, emptiness, and voidness
does his utility never fail.

Now, fullness is not emptiness,
emptiness is not fullness—
yet today, fullness seems empty,
forgetting fullness, forgetting emptiness.
Thus, he is both empty and full,
full yet seeming empty.

Great rectitude is like bending,
*—Commentary:* Great rectitude refers to the upright practice of *Dao* and law,
yet bending, like one who does not contend with the vulgar,
as if yielding and pliable.
*—Exegesis:* The one of great simplicity and sincerity
does not display his rectitude openly,
thus blending with the common, bending with things—
hence, he seems bent.
Thus, true rectitude surpasses petty rectitude.

Great skill is like clumsiness,
*—Commentary:* Great skill refers to abundant talents and achievements,
yet seeming clumsy, he does not dare to display his abilities.
*—Exegesis:* The artisan who crafts myriad things,
the smith who forges all life—
though possessing great skill and achievement,
he forgets his craft and utility,
hiding his traces among the common—
thus, he seems clumsy.
*Zhuangzi* says:
*"He carves and shapes all forms yet does not consider it skillful."*
Thus, true skill surpasses petty skill.

Great eloquence is like inarticulateness.
*—Commentary:* Great eloquence is unquestionable wisdom;
yet seeming inarticulate, he has no verbal adornment.
*—Master Gu’s Explanation:* He does not embellish with trivial tales.
*—Exegesis:* The one whose profound insight dissects true emptiness,
measuring the utmost mysteries—
his speech is beyond speech.
He does not conform to the world’s ways.
Swift and sharp in talent, thus his speech is halting and inarticulate.
*Zhuangzi* says:
*"The unsaid eloquence"*—also, *"Great eloquence does not speak."*
Thus, true eloquence surpasses petty eloquence.

Frenzy overcomes cold,
*—Commentary:* *Sheng* means extreme.

chunks.original_text: 春夏阳气躁疾於上，万物盛极则寒，寒则零落死亡也。 言人不当刚躁也。 静胜热。 注：秋冬万物静於黄泉之下，极则热，热者生之原也。 ○疏：躁，阳也。 静，阴也。 胜，极也。 言四时运转，阴极阳生，阳极阴起。 阴起故一切凋落。 阳生故庶物咸盛。 喻静是长生之本，躁是死灭之原，以劝行人去躁归静也。 又解：从本降迹，即躁胜寒。 患迹归本，即静胜热。 以明动静适时也。 ○顾曰：物极则反，动极则静，静极则动，从此而观，盛极则衰，衰极则盛，人间诸法，例皆如此。 既非常保，何所贪求。 是以圣人不取不求，无得无失，而五种大行，自清自静，不为寒热所侵，始为天下之正主云云。 清静以为天下正。 注：能清能静，则为天下长，持正则无终已时也。 ○疏：清虚宁静，可以自利利他，以正治邪，故为天下正。 此则结释静胜躁，优劣之义也。 ○节解曰：谓得入深山，行清净，守自然，则为真人也。 天下有道， 注：谓人主有道也。

The vitality of spring and summer ascends swiftly and fiercely above—when all things reach their utmost flourishing, cold ensues, and cold brings withering and death. Thus, it is said that one should not align with rigid excess.

*Qi* of stillness overcomes heat.
*—Commentary:* In autumn and winter, all things rest beneath the Yellow Springs—when stillness reaches its extreme, heat arises, and heat is the source of life. ○*Exegesis:* *Liao* (frenzy) is the *yang* (active, bright). Stillness is the *yin* (passive, dark). *Sheng* (overcomes) means extreme. It speaks of the four seasons’ cyclical turn: when *yin* reaches its peak, *yang* emerges; when *yang* reaches its peak, *yin* arises. *Yin*’s emergence causes all things to wither; *yang*’s emergence causes all things to flourish. It analogizes stillness as the foundation of longevity, while frenzy is the root of decay, urging practitioners to abandon frenzy and return to stillness. Again, it explains: descending from the origin to its manifestation, we see frenzy overcoming cold. Returning from the manifestation to the origin, we see stillness overcoming heat. This clarifies how movement and stillness adapt to their proper times.

*—Master Gu’s Explanation:* All things pushed to their limit invert. Movement pushed to its limit becomes stillness; stillness pushed to its limit becomes movement. Observing this, we see that extreme flourishing leads to decline, and extreme decline leads to flourishing—all phenomena in the world follow this pattern. Since it is not the norm to preserve, what should one covet or seek? Therefore, the sage takes nothing, seeks nothing, gains nothing, loses nothing, and in the five great practices of *Dao*, remains naturally pure and still, unaffected by cold or heat. Only then can he be the true master of the world, as it is said: *"He who clears and stills himself becomes the rightful master of the world."*

*—Commentary:* To clear and still oneself is to become the rightful master of the world. *Clearing* and *stillness* ensure enduring rectitude, and holding to the *Dao* means there is no end to its timelessness.

*—Exegesis:* Pure, tranquil, and at ease—one can benefit himself and others, rectify what is wrong and suppress what is perverse. Thus, he becomes the rightful master of the world. This then concludes the exposition of stillness overcoming frenzy, clarifying the distinction between excellence and mediocrity.

*—Master Jie’s Explanation:* It refers to entering deep mountains, practicing purity, and abiding in nature—then one becomes a true person. When the *Dao* prevails in the world, *—Commentary:* Meaning when the ruler of the world follows the *Dao*—

chunks.original_text: 却走马以粪。 注：粪，田也。 兵甲不用，却走马以治田农也。 治身者，却阳精以粪其 身也。 ○御曰：有道之主，无为化行，既不贪求，故无交战，屏却走马 之事，人得粪於田园。 ○疏：言有道之君，种於天下，干戈静息，偃武 修文，宇内清夷，无为而治，故能却驰走之马，以粪农田。 治身者却六 根兵马，以道粪心，故孟子云：人皆以粪粪其田而莫之以学粪其心也。 天下无道， 注：谓人主无道。 戎马生於郊。 注：战伐不止，戎马生於郊境之上，久不还也。 ○疏：郭外日郊，无道之君，临於海内，禽荒色荒，四方不静，多贪境土，好行征伐，遂使军戎兵马出生郊外。 且轻身躁竞之夫，心不怀道，纵於六根兵马，驰骋尘境之中，故云生於郊也。 罪莫大於可欲， 注：好色欲也。 ○疏：罪者摧也，言为苦之所摧逼也。 前境美丽，称可欲之心，故言可欲也。 然境能逼心，是起罪之绿，以戒行人不可染境也。 故上经云：不见可欲，使心不乱。 祸莫大於知不足， 注：富贵不能自禁止。 ○疏：祸即罪之深重者也，言心贪前境，不知厌足，害人损物，为罪日深，非唯灾及一身，亦乃祸延三族。 咎莫甚於欲得。 注：欲得人物，利且贵也。 ○御曰：殃咎之大，莫大於欲，欲得祸深，故云咎也。 ○疏：咎，考责也，欲得之心，略无涯际，其为咎责，莫甚於斯，格量深浅，祸重咎轻，欲备显物情，故具彰二衅。 故知足之足， 注：守真根也。 常足矣。 注：无欲也。 ○疏：守分不食於行便足，恒无阙少，故言常足。 欲明贵竞之类，遭祸遇殃，知足之人，恒居安泰，先病后药，故继此文。 不出户，知天下。 注：圣人不出户以知天下者，以己身知人身，以己家知人家，所以见天下也。 ○疏：户者谓知觉，攀绿分别，等门户也。 有道之人虚怀内静，不驰心於世境，而天下之事悉知，此以真照俗也。 不窥牖，以见天道。 注：天道与人道同，天人相通，精气相贯，人君清静，天气自正，人君多欲，天炁烦浊，吉凶利害，皆由於己。 ○御曰：垂拱无为，不出教令於户外，而天道可知也。 ○疏：牖，根窍也，天道自然之理，寨体坐忘，不窥根窍，而真心内朗，睹见自然之道，此以智照真也。 户通来去，从真照俗，窗牖内闭，喻返照真源也。 其出弥远，其知弥少。 注：谓去其家观人家，去其身观人身，所观益远，所知益少。 ○疏：颠倒之夫，不能照理，其心逐境，弥远而无厌，其知浅近，暗昧而少鉴。 是以圣人不行而知， 注：圣人不上天，不入渊，能知天下者，以心知之也。 ○疏：不行者，心不绿历前境而知者，能体知诸法实相，譬悬镜高堂，物来斯照，而无心也，故《庄子》云：圣人不由心而照之于天矣。 不见而名， 注：上好道，下好德，上好武，下好力，圣人原小以知大，察内以知外。 ○疏：不见者，了知诸法虚幻，无可见之物也。 而名者能正名百物，垂迹显教，不见而损情欲，文饰日以消损也。 ○御曰：不窥牖，故云不见，人和天顺，故能名其太平。 不为而成。 注：上无所为则下无事，家给人足，万物自化就也。 ○疏：不为者，凝神寂澹，绝於有为也。 而成者能施化群品，成就学人，此明寂而动也。 为学日益， 注：学者谓政教礼乐之学也，日益  者，情欲文饰，日以益多。

However, the warhorses are turned to plowing fields.
*—Commentary:* "Plowing" (粪) here means tilling. It signifies that when arms are not used, warhorses are instead employed to cultivate the fields. For those cultivating the self, it means channeling the vital essence of *yang* to nourish the body.

*—Master Yu’s Explanation:* A ruler who follows the *Dao* governs through *wu-wei*, his actions free from greed, thus avoiding warfare. He dispenses with the use of warhorses, allowing people to till the fields. For those cultivating the self, it means restraining the six senses—like an army—to till the heart with the *Dao*. Hence, Mencius said: *"All till their fields with dung, but none till their hearts with learning."*

When the *Dao* prevails in the world,
*—Commentary:* Meaning when the ruler of the world follows the *Dao*—

the warhorses are stabled at the outskirts.
*—Commentary:* Constant warfare keeps warhorses stationed at the borders, never returning. *—Exegesis:* The outskirts are called *jiao* (郊). A ruler without the *Dao* oppresses his people, causing chaos. Greedy for territory, he wages endless wars, forcing military horses to remain permanently beyond the borders. Moreover, those who are reckless and competitive, their hearts devoid of the *Dao*, let their six senses—like an army—gallop through the dusty realm, hence the saying that they "generate at the outskirts."

No guilt is greater than indulging desire.
*—Commentary:* Lustful desire. *—Exegesis:* "Guilt" (罪) means ruin—being overwhelmed by suffering. When one encounters alluring sights that stir the heart’s craving, it is called "desirable." Yet, if external phenomena can ensnare the mind, they become the root of sin. Thus, the previous passage states: *"Do not see what is desirable, lest the heart be disturbed."*

No calamity is greater than knowing insufficiency.
*—Commentary:* Wealth and honor cannot restrain oneself. *—Exegesis:* "Calamity" is the deepest form of guilt—when the heart clings to external phenomena, never satisfied, harming others and depleting resources. The guilt grows ever deeper, not just afflicting oneself but extending to three generations.

No blame is graver than the craving to possess.
*—Master Yu’s Explanation:* The greatest misfortune is desire; its consequences are deep, hence "blame." *—Exegesis:* "Blame" (咎) means censure. The heart’s craving for possession knows no bounds—its censure is unparalleled. Comparing the depths of guilt and calamity, the latter is heavier, while blame is lighter. To fully reveal human nature, both are made explicit.

Thus, the sufficiency of *knowing sufficiency*,
*—Commentary:* Preserving the true root—
is ever sufficient.
*—Commentary:* Free from desire. *—Exegesis:* One who adheres to their proper place, without indulging in external pursuits, is always complete, never lacking.

Without stepping outside,
one knows the world.
*—Commentary:* The sage does not step outside yet knows the world because they understand others through themselves, and others’ families through their own. *—Exegesis:* "Outside" refers to perception, discrimination, and the gates of the senses. The virtuous person, with an empty mind and inner stillness, does not let their thoughts wander into external phenomena, yet knows all under heaven. This is true illumination reflecting the mundane.

Without peering through the window,
one perceives the *Dao* of Heaven.
*—Commentary:* The *Dao* of Heaven and humanity are the same; Heaven and man are interconnected, their vital *qi* flowing together. When a ruler is pure and still, Heaven’s *qi* aligns naturally. When a ruler is greedy, Heaven’s *qi* becomes turbulent and impure. All fortune, misfortune, benefit, and harm arise from within oneself. *—Master Yu’s Explanation:* With hands resting and *wu-wei* governance, no decrees are issued beyond the door, yet the *Dao* of Heaven is known. *—Exegesis:* The window (牖) refers to the sensory orifices. The *Dao* of Heaven is the natural principle. In a state of forgetfulness, seated and still, one does not gaze through the sensory gates, yet the true heart shines brightly, revealing the natural *Dao*. This is wisdom illuminating truth.

The door allows passage in and out—
from true illumination to the mundane.
The window, when closed within—
a return to the true source.

The farther one goes,
the less one knows.
*—Commentary:* Observing others’ families from afar, others’ bodies from a distance—what is observed grows farther, and what is known grows less. *—Exegesis:* Those who are inverted cannot perceive truth; their minds follow phenomena, ever distant yet never satisfied. Their knowledge is shallow and obscured, lacking discernment.

Thus, the sage acts without going,
yet knows all.
*—Commentary:* The sage does not ascend to Heaven nor descend into the abyss, yet knows the world through the mind. *—Exegesis:* "Acts without going" means the mind does not cling to external phenomena yet knows all things in their true nature. Like a mirror hung in a hall, objects pass before it and are reflected without effort. Hence, *Zhuangzi* says: *"The sage does not use the mind to illuminate Heaven."*

Without seeing,
one names.
*—Commentary:* The ruler cherishes the *Dao*, the people cherish virtue; the ruler values martial prowess, the people value strength. The sage infers the great from the small, the external from the internal. *—Exegesis:* "Without seeing" means penetrating the emptiness of all phenomena, for there is nothing visible. "Names" refers to rectifying names and classifying all things, leaving traces and manifesting teachings. Without seeing, one diminishes emotional attachments and ornamental excesses daily. *—Master Yu’s Explanation:* Since one does not peer through the window, it is said, "without seeing." When humanity and Heaven are in harmony, one can name the era of great peace.

Without doing,
one achieves.
*—Commentary:* If the ruler does nothing, the people have no tasks; households are prosperous, and all things transform naturally. *—Exegesis:* "Without doing" means concentrating the spirit in stillness, abandoning all action. "Achieves" refers to nurturing all beings and perfecting those who learn—this illustrates stillness in motion.

For those who study,
daily increase.
*—Commentary:* "Those who study" refers to governance, teaching, rites, and music. "Daily increase" means emotional desires and ornamental excesses grow ever more.

chunks.original_text: ○疏：  为，修营也。 学，俗学也。 言修俗学  之人，锐情分别，故累欲日增也。 为道日损。 注：道谓自然之道，日损者，使情欲  文饰日以消损也。 ○御曰：为学日  益见闻，为道者日损功行。 益见闻  者，为修学之渐，损功行者，为悟道  之门，是故因益以积功，功忘而体道  矣。 ○疏：为道谓修道也。 言修道  之士，虚夷恬淡，所以智德渐明，累惑日消也。 损之又损之， 注：损之者，损情欲也。 又损之者，所以渐去也。 以至於无为。 注：当恬淡如婴儿，无所造为也。 ○疏：为学之人，执於有欲，为道之士，又滞於无为，虽复深浅不同，而俱有患。 今欲治此两执，故有损益之文，既而前损损有，后损损无，二偏双遣，以至於一中之无为也。 无为而无不为也。 注：情欲断绝，德与道合，则无所不施，无所不为也。 ○御曰：为学积功行，为道忘损之，虽损功行，尚有欲损之心，兼忘此心，至於淡然无为。 方彼镜象而无不应，故无不为。 ○疏：即寂而动，即体而用，故无不为也。 上经云：道常无为无不为。 取天下常以无事， 注：取，治也。 治天下常当以无事，不当烦劳也。 ○疏：取，摄化也。 言摄取宇内苍生，令其归善者，常以无为无事而化之也。 虽复应物施为，而心未常有事，此即动而寂也。 故《庄子》云：孰弊弊焉，以物为事乎。 及其有事，不足以取天下。 注：及其好有事，则政教烦民不安，故不足以治天下也。 ○疏：其心未虚忘，以事为事而有事者，斯事异无事，无事异事，动异於寂，寂乖於动，如此之人，不足以摄化天下也。 圣人无心， 注：圣人不重改更，贵因循，若似无心也。 以百姓心为心。 注：百姓心之所便，因而从之。 ○疏：体道洞忘，虚怀绝虑，与死灰均 其寂泊，故无心也。 百姓，众生也。 然圣人无心，有感斯应，应随物感， 故以百姓心为心，心既无心，心应亦不应。 ○节解曰：谓知道行气以神 为心，则流布百节，百节百神百名共於形中，故日以百姓心为心也。 善者吾善之， 注：百姓为善，圣人因而善之。 不善者吾亦善之， 注：百姓虽有不善者，圣人化之使为善也。 ○疏：善者谓无欲修学之士也，不善者谓有为滞境之人。 普以平等胜教化之，令其得善，此则以百姓心为心之善也。 德善矣。 注：圣人德化，百姓为善矣。 ○节解曰：谓行一养神，神和形柔，邪去正存，骨坚随真，故日得善矣。 信者吾信之， 注：百姓为信，圣人因而信之。 不信者吾亦信之， 注：百姓为不信，圣人化之使信也。 德信矣。 注：圣人德化，百姓为信矣。 ○御曰：欲善信者，吾因而善信之。 不信者，吾亦以善信教之，令百姓感吾德而善信之也。 ○疏：信谓闻经戒爱乐，不信谓不乐道文，圣人以空行慈悲，平等救度，不问信与不信，皆令得益，而普发信心。 故真迹紫微夫人曰：信者得失之关键。 又经云：信者学道之枢机也。 一问日：圣人无心，有感必应，不感不应者，则信者方教，不信者不教，而令信与不信，一种教之，亦应感与不感，一种皆应。 答曰：应有通有别，如治在玄都玉京，而恒救三界，此则通应善信是也。 至如胡人有感紫炁西浮，授尹真人道德之文，此则别应。

「○ *Exegesis:* "For" means cultivating and embellishing. "Learn" refers to mundane studies. It speaks of those who cultivate mundane learning—with sharp emotions and discriminating minds, their desires thus accumulate daily. "For Dao daily diminishes" means they act in accordance with the Way of Nature, causing their desires and embellishments to be daily eroded away.

○ *Master Yu’s Explanation:* Those who study accumulate knowledge daily, while those who follow the Dao diminish their deeds. "Accumulating knowledge" is the gradual progression of mundane study, while "diminishing deeds" is the gateway to enlightenment. Thus, through accumulation, one cultivates virtue, and in forgetting virtue, one attains the Dao itself.

○ *Exegesis:* "For Dao" means cultivating the Dao. It speaks of those who cultivate the Dao—with empty minds and tranquil ease, their wisdom and virtue gradually become clear, and their delusions daily dissipate. "Diminish again, diminish again" means diminishing desires once more, and again, so as to gradually eliminate them, until reaching the state of *wuwei* (non-action).

○ *Exegesis:* Those who study cling to desires, while those who follow the Dao are hindered by the notion of *wuwei*. Though their depths differ, both suffer afflictions. Now, to correct these two extremes, there is the text on diminishing and augmenting. First, diminish and diminish desires; later, diminish and diminish the fixation on *wuwei*. With both extremes dispelled, one attains the non-action of the central path. In non-action, there is nothing that is not done.

○ *Exegesis:* This is the Dao of stillness in motion, of embodying yet applying—thus, there is nothing that is not done. The earlier section states: "The Dao is ever *wuwei* yet ever *wuwei*." To govern the realm, one must always do so without exertion—never burdening the people with laborious tasks.

○ *Exegesis:* "Govern" means to transform and guide. It speaks of those who transform and guide all under Heaven, leading them to goodness, always through *wuwei* and non-exertion. Though they respond to things and act accordingly, their minds remain undisturbed—this is stillness within motion. Hence, *Zhuangzi* says: "Who is it that wears himself out, making things his business?" When one truly has affairs, he is unfit to govern the realm.

○ *Exegesis:* When his mind is not yet empty and forgetful, treating affairs as his business and thus having affairs, this is different from true *wuwei*. True *wuwei* is distinct from having affairs; motion differs from stillness, and stillness contradicts motion. Such a person is unfit to transform and guide the realm.

○ *Exegesis:* The Sage has no mind—never altering his ways, valuing steadfastness, as if without mind. He takes the hearts of the people as his own—following what they find convenient.

○ *Exegesis:* In embodying the Dao, he penetrates and forgets all things, his mind empty and free from thought, like still ashes. Thus, he has no mind. The people are all beings. Though the Sage has no mind, he responds to all stimuli—his responses follow the sensations of things. Hence, he takes the hearts of the people as his own, yet in having no mind, his responses are also without responses.

○ *Master Yu’s Explanation:* "The Sage’s heart is without heart, yet it responds to all stimuli." Thus, those who are already trustworthy, he trusts them; those who are not, he also trusts them. When the people’s virtue is good, the Sage’s virtue is also good. When the people are trustworthy, the Sage trusts them; when they are not, he also trusts them. When the people’s virtue is good, the Sage’s virtue is also good.

○ *Master Yu’s Explanation:* Those who desire goodness and trustworthiness, I follow them accordingly. Those who are not trustworthy, I also teach them goodness and trustworthiness, so that the people are moved by my virtue to become good and trustworthy.

○ *Exegesis:* Trustworthiness means taking delight in hearing the *dharma* and precepts, while lack of trust means not rejoicing in the Dao’s teachings. The Sage, through empty practice and compassion, universally transforms and guides all beings equally, regardless of trust or doubt, so that all may benefit and universally awaken faith. Hence, the *Zhenji* of *Zhenwei* says: "Trust is the key to gain or loss." The *sutra* also states: "Trust is the pivot of learning the Dao."

One question: If the Sage has no mind, yet responds to all stimuli, and does not respond when there are none, then does he teach those who are trustworthy but not those who are not? Yet the text says that both trustworthy and untrustworthy are taught in the same way, and so too with stimuli and non-stimuli—all are responded to alike.

The answer: There is both universal and particular response. Like treating illness in the *Xuan Du* Palace of Jade Clarity, yet always saving the Three Realms—this is universal response. As for the barbarians who, upon sensing the *Zhi* of Purple Qi, receive the *Dao* from *Yin* the True Person—this is particular response.

*—Commentary:* "Those who study" refers to governance, teaching, rites, and music. "Daily increase" means emotional desires and ornamental excesses grow ever more.

chunks.original_text: 若别应则待别感，通应则寻常慈照，故上经云：常善救人而无弃人也。 ○节解曰：谓人信一也，一亦信人，人不信一，一由人生，故道常得其信也。 圣人在天下怵怵， 注：圣人在天下，常怵怵恐惧，富贵不敢骄奢。 ○疏：怵怵，动惧之貌也，言无心赴感。 圣人其在天下也，恒布大慈，护救苍生，恐其没溺，故怵怵而动惧也。 为天下浑其心， 注：圣人为天下百姓混浊其心，若愚暗不通也。 ○疏：浑沌，无分别也。 言凡夫感情滞境，妄生去取，圣人欲浑沌其心，令无分别，勤惧之义，即斯谓也。 百姓皆注其耳目， 注：注，用也。 百姓皆用其耳目，为圣人视听。 ○疏：河上作注，诸本作淫。 淫者染滞也，颠倒之徒，迷没世境，纵恣耳目，滞着声色，既而漂浪长流，愆非日积，圣人愍其困苦，故显其病。 六根之中，遍举两者，欲明此二患最深。 故《西升经》云：耳目声色为子留愆，然举一根，诸根可悉，为文备故也。 圣人皆孩之。 注：圣人爱念百姓，如育赤子，长养之而不责望其报。 ○疏：众生妄淫耳目，沦没爱河，圣人勤惧慈救，义同赤子，哀其无识，故如婴儿之可愍。 出生入死。 注：出生，谓情欲出於五内，魂定魄静，故生也。 入死，谓情欲入於胸臆，精神劳惑，故死也。 ○御曰：了悟则出生，迷执则入死。 ○疏：出生者，超凌三界，出离死生。 入死者，沈沦三涂，没溺生死，若解生死义者，从无出有，以释生为生，自有还无，以释灭为死。 生之徒十有三，死之徒十有三。 注：言生死之类，各有十三，谓九窍四关也。 其生也，目不妄视，耳不妄听，鼻不妄嗅，口不妄言，舌不妄味，手不妄持，足不妄行，精不妄施，其死也反是。 ○疏：徒，类也。 言九窍四关，凡圣俱有，圣人忘之，故出三界。 凡夫执着，故入六道。 入六道则死之徒，出三界则生之徒。 人之生，动之死地亦十有三。 注：人欲求生动作，反之十三死地也。 ○疏：凡人之生动即适死地者，盖为执此十三，滞於前境故也。 夫何故？ 注：问之何故，动之死地也。 ○疏：假设疑问，以生后答。 以其生生之厚。 注：所以动之死地者，以其求生活之事太厚，违道件天，妄行失纪也。 ○疏：言人不能体道忘生，而执生为有，多积物产，厚资此生而营生过当，故动之死地，此一句答前问意也。 盖闻善摄生者， 注：摄，养也。 ○疏：盖不尽问之辞，犹窃闻也。 摄，卫也，养也。 言善摄卫养生之人，淡泊虚夷，不染尘境，摄卫之美，自显下文。 陆行不遇兕虎， 注：自然远避，害不干也。 ○疏：陆，平地也。 兕，毒兽，一角，形如野牛，青色。 言善摄生之人，不为毒兽所触。 内解者言，平居安静，不为烦恼所加也。 入军不被甲兵。 注：不好战以杀也。 ○疏：言摄生之人，不入行阵，亦不为干戈所害。 内解者，纵入尘境，亦不为色等所伤。 兕无所投其角，虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃。 注：养生之人，兕虎无由伤，兵刃无由加也。 ○御曰：善摄理生之人，心照清净，无贪取之意，故外物不可加害。 ○疏：诸本言驻。 驻，立也，措，安也，兕遇物即触，喻痴人也。 虎性躁暴，喻啧也。 兵刃锐利，能伤於人，喻食也。 言善摄生者，妙体真空，故虽处世问，而不为三毒所害也。
chunks.translated_text:
If the response is particular, it awaits particular stimuli; if universal, it is ever-present with boundless compassion. Hence the *sutra* says: *"Ever saving all beings without abandoning any."*

**Explication:**
It means that when a person is trustworthy, trust is one; when trust is one, it trusts the person. If a person does not trust the One, the One arises from the person, so the Dao ever attains its trust.

The Sage moves through the world with constant reverence—
*Note:* The Sage, moving through the world, is ever reverent and fearful, never daring to indulge in arrogance or excess from wealth and honor.

**Commentary:** *Reverence* (*chùchù*)—the form of ceaseless fear—speaks of having no mind to respond to stimuli.

The Sage, dwelling in the world, ever spreads great compassion, protecting and saving all beings, fearing they may perish or drown. Thus, he moves with constant reverence and fear.

He muddles the hearts of the people—
*Note:* The Sage muddles the hearts of the common folk, as if making them dull and unknowing.

**Commentary:** *Muddled* (*húntūn*)—without distinction. It speaks of how ordinary people, ensnared by emotions and entangled in the world, foolishly grasp at gain and loss. The Sage desires to muddle their hearts, leaving them without distinction, and this is the meaning of his constant fear and reverence.

All the people focus their ears and eyes—
*Note:* *Focus* (*zhù*)—to use.

All the people use their ears and eyes as the Sage’s eyes and ears.

**Commentary:** The *River Above* text reads *zhù* (focus), while other versions read *yín* (indulgence). *Indulgence* means to be stained and entangled; those who are deluded and inverted, lost in the world, give free rein to their ears and eyes, clinging to sounds and colors. Later, they drift adrift in endless wandering, accumulating faults day by day. The Sage pities their suffering, so he reveals their affliction.

Among the six senses, two are highlighted to show these two afflictions are the deepest.
Thus the *Sutra of Western Ascension* says: *"Ears and eyes, sounds and colors—these are the children’s faults."* Yet by mentioning one sense, all senses are implied, for completeness’ sake.

The Sage treats them all like infants—
*Note:* The Sage loves and cares for the people as if they were newborn children, nurturing them without expecting repayment.

**Commentary:** Ordinary beings indulge their ears and eyes, drowning in the river of desire. The Sage, with constant fear and compassion, acts like one who pities infants, grieving their ignorance.

They are born and they die.
*Note:* *Born*—when emotions arise from within, the spirit is settled, the soul is still, hence *born*. *Die*—when emotions enter the chest, the spirit is confused and agitated, hence *death*.

**Commentary:** *Born*—transcending the Three Realms, free from birth and death.
*Die*—sinking into the Three Paths, drowning in birth and death. If one understands the meaning of birth and death, it is from non-being to being, releasing *birth* as *birth*; from being back to non-being, releasing *extinction* as *death*.

There are thirteen kinds of those who are born, and thirteen kinds of those who die.
*Note:* It speaks of the thirteen types of birth and death—namely, the nine orifices and four passages.

In their birth: the eyes do not gaze wantonly, the ears do not listen wantonly, the nose does not sniff wantonly, the mouth does not speak wantonly, the tongue does not taste wantonly, the hands do not grasp wantonly, the feet do not walk wantonly, the vital essence is not expended wantonly. In their death, it is the opposite.

**Commentary:** *Kinds* (*tú*)—types. The nine orifices and four passages belong to both sages and ordinary beings. The Sage forgets them, thus transcending the Three Realms. Ordinary beings cling to them, thus entering the Six Paths. Entering the Six Paths is the kind of death; transcending the Three Realms is the kind of birth.

A person’s life moves toward thirteen kinds of death.
*Note:* When a person seeks life through action, it reverses into thirteen kinds of death.

**Commentary:** When a person’s life is directed toward death, it is because they cling to these thirteen (senses), becoming entangled in the world before them.

Why is this so?
*Note:* Asking why one moves toward death through action.

**Commentary:** A rhetorical question, answered below.

Because their attachment to life is excessive.
*Note:* The reason one moves toward death through action is that their pursuit of life is too heavy, contrary to the Dao and Heaven, acting recklessly and losing measure.

**Commentary:** It speaks of how people cannot embody the Dao and forget life, instead clinging to life as real, accumulating wealth and resources, overindulging in life’s concerns, thus moving toward death. This sentence answers the prior question.

Indeed, it is heard that those who skillfully nurture life—
*Note:* *Nurture* (*shè*)—to guard, to nourish.

**Commentary:** *Indeed*—not a direct answer, akin to *"I have heard."* *Nurture*—to guard, to nourish. It speaks of how those who skillfully guard and nourish life are simple and unadorned, untouched by the world. The excellence of their guardianship is shown below.

When walking on land, they avoid rhinoceroses and tigers—
*Note:* Naturally avoiding harm, which does not reach them.

**Commentary:** *Land*—flat ground. *Rhinoceros*—a poisonous beast with one horn, resembling a wild ox, green in color. It speaks of how those who nurture life skillfully are not harmed by poisonous beasts. Internally, it means they remain calm and undisturbed by afflictions in daily life.

Entering battle, they are unharmed by armor and weapons—
*Note:* They do not love war or killing.

**Commentary:** It speaks of how those who nurture life do not enter battlefields and are not harmed by weapons. Internally, even if they enter the world, they are not injured by desires.

Rhinoceroses have no place to strike with their horns, tigers no place to place their claws, weapons no place to lodge their blades—
*Note:* Those who nurture life skillfully are not injured by rhinoceroses or tigers, nor harmed by weapons.

**Commentary:** Other texts say *zhù* (stationary). *Stationary*—to stand; *place*—to settle. Rhinoceroses, encountering objects, charge; this allegorizes the foolish. Tigers are fierce and violent; this allegorizes greed. Weapons are sharp and can harm people; this allegorizes gluttony. It speaks of how those who nurture life skillfully embody true emptiness, so even amid the world, they are unharmed by the Three Poisons.

chunks.original_text: 夫何故？ 注：问虎兕兵甲何故不害之也。 ○疏：假设疑问有何事，故得政如此。 以其无死地。 注：以其不犯上十三之死地也，言神明营护之，此物自然不敢害也。 ○御曰：以其顺化无私，不以死为死，则物不得害其生，故云无死地也。 ○疏：夫见有身者，故以身为死地也。 今善摄生之人，忘於身相，即身无身，故无地之可死也。 既无死地，三毒何所加乎。 ○节解曰：谓圣人怀精神守一，行气握固胎息，故使此物不害之。 道处其心，真气俱存，故无刑杀之地也。 道生之， 注：道生万物。 德畜之。 注：德，一也，一生布炁而畜养之也。 ○御曰：物得以生，养万类也。 ○疏：至道虚玄，通生万物，上德慈救，畜养群生也，故云道生德畜也。 物形之， 注：一为万物设形象。 势成之。 注：亦云势成之，一为万物作寒暑炁势以成之。 ○疏：陶莹心灵，令行业淳熟而成就也。 是以万物莫不尊道而贵德。 注：道德所为，无不尽惊动而尊敬之也。 ○御曰：万物皆由道德以生畜，故尊贵之。 ○疏：道德生育，具如前旨，苍生荷赖，日用不知，是以劝示令崇尚也。 道尊德贵，夫莫之爵而常自然。 注：道一不命召万物而常自然，应之如影响也。 ○御曰：言道德之尊贵，非假爵命，但生成之功，被物而常，自然贵也。 ○疏：世上尊荣，必须品秩，所以非久。 而道德尊贵，无关爵命，故常自然。 故道生之、畜之、长之、育之、成之、熟之、养之、覆之。 注：言道之於万物，非但生之而已，乃复长养成熟覆育，全其性命。 人君治国治身，亦当如此。 ○疏：重迭前文，以生后句。 而举道不言德者，明德不异道，而文略故也。 《西升经》云：道德浑沌，玄妙同也。 长之者，谓增其善芽。 育之者，谓进其功行也。 成熟者，谓以无上妙法，莹饰物心，令其道果成就，德业淳熟，此犹迭前语，来生后文也。 养覆者，养谓酬其果报，覆谓鹰以大慈也。 已上四双，明利物之德，以下三德，明能遣其功也。 生而不有， 注：道生万物，不有所取，以为利用。 ○疏：虽复能生万物，实无物之可生，刍狗其情，故即生而不有，有即有而不有，生亦生而不生，此遣道生之也。 为而不侍， 注：道所施为，不恃望其报。 ○疏：既生成万物，不有其生，施为法教，於何可恃，此遣德畜之也。 长而不宰， 注：道长养万物，不宰割以为利用也。 ○疏：长养苍生，功伴造化，而能所俱幻，谁其宰乎，此遣长之等四双也。 是谓玄德。 注：道之所行，恩德玄暗，不可得见也。 ○疏：是则指於上句，谓则言及下文。 玄者深远之名，德以证护为义，指前体道之士，利物忘功，以法目人，可谓玄德。 ○车曰：道为阳极，阳即天也。 天以运动，所以生万物。 德为阴极，阴即地也，地以包含，所以畜万物。 受炁日生，养形曰畜，所云一切万物之形势。 成之者，因其业势而成就之。 业势应合为人，即为作人形而成就之。 ○蔡曰：为诸众生作四时之势，成就万物，此说在前。 天下有始， 注：始有道也。 以为天下母。 注：道为天下万物母也。 ○御曰：始者冲和之妙黑也，言此妙炁生成万物，有茂养之德，故可以为天下母也。 ○疏：始道本母，道述也，夫玄道妙本，大智慧源，超绝名言，离诸色象，天下万物，皆从此生。
chunks.translated_text:
Why is this so?

*—Asking why tigers, rhinoceroses, and weapons do not harm them.*

For they dwell in the realm of no-death.

*—Because they do not violate the thirteen forbidden grounds of death, the numinous protects them, and these creatures dare not harm them.*

*—The Way flows naturally without partiality; they do not regard death as death, so things cannot harm their life—thus, the realm of no-death.*

*—Those who perceive form as form regard the body as the ground of death. But those who practice life-nurturing skillfully forget bodily form—when form is forgotten, there is no ground for death. Without the ground of death, how could the Three Poisons take hold?*

*—The Sage embraces spirit and unity, regulates qi and stabilizes the fetal breath, thus these creatures cannot harm them. The Dao dwells in the heart, and true qi abides—there is no ground for execution.*

The Dao gives birth to them,
Virtue nurtures them,
Form shapes them,
Momentum completes them.

*—The Dao generates all things. Virtue (unity) spreads qi and nurtures them.*

*—The Supreme Dao is boundless and mysterious, generating all things; supreme virtue is compassionate and sustains all life—thus, "the Dao gives birth, virtue nurtures."*

*—It endows them with form and momentum to complete them.*

*—Thus all things reverence the Dao and honor virtue.*

*—All things arise from the Dao and virtue; hence, they are revered.*

*—The Dao and virtue are honored not by titles but by their natural operation.*

*—The Dao’s honor and virtue’s nobility require no artificial elevation—they are naturally so.*

Thus the Dao:
Gives birth to them,
Nurtures them,
Lengthens them,
Cultivates them,
Perfects them,
Matures them,
Sustains them,
Covers them.

*—The Dao’s work for all things is not merely to give birth but to lengthen, nurture, perfect, mature, sustain, and cover—fulfilling their nature and life.*

*—This mirrors the ruler’s governance of state and self.*

*—The text repeats earlier phrases to introduce what follows. The Dao is mentioned without virtue because virtue does not differ from the Dao, though the text is concise for brevity.*

As the *Western Ascension Scripture* says:
*"The Dao and virtue are indistinct and mysteriously unified."*

Lengthening refers to fostering their virtuous sprouts.
Cultivating refers to advancing their deeds.
Perfecting and maturing refers to refining their hearts with supreme teachings, so their Dao is fulfilled and their virtue perfected—this echoes prior language to lead into the next passage.
Sustaining and covering: sustaining refers to rewarding their fruits; covering refers to sheltering with boundless compassion.

The four pairs above clarify the virtue of benefiting all things; the three below clarify the Dao’s self-effacing function.

Giving birth yet not possessing,
Acting yet not relying,
Lengthening yet not controlling—
This is called the Mysterious Virtue.

*—The Dao’s operation is an unfathomable benevolence, invisible yet profound.*

*—This refers to the passage above, introducing what follows. "Mysterious" denotes depth; "virtue" signifies protective fulfillment. It points to those who embody the Dao, benefiting others while forgetting their own deeds, guiding people with the law—truly Mysterious Virtue.*

*—The Dao is the apex of yang, yang being heaven. Heaven moves, thus generating all things. Virtue is the apex of yin, yin being earth; earth encompasses, thus nurturing all things. Receiving qi is birth; nurturing form is sustenance—the forms and momentum of all things. Perfecting refers to completing them through their deeds and momentum, forming human shape.*

*—The Dao endows all beings with the four seasonal rhythms, completing all things—this explanation precedes.*

At the origin of all things lies the Dao,
Which becomes the mother of all under heaven.

*—The origin is the subtle black of primordial harmony; this mysterious qi generates all things with nourishing virtue, thus it can be the mother of all under heaven.*

*—The Dao is the primordial mother; this is its description. The mysterious Dao is the source of great wisdom, transcending names and forms, beyond all colored appearances. All things under heaven arise from it.*
